quote: One of them, seeing he was healed, returned praising God.
firstReading: The Wisdom passage urges an eager search for divine wisdom and moral vigilance. It calls listeners to value prudence and to seek wisdom early as one would seek treasure, instructing them to prepare like watchmen awaiting daybreak. The text stresses readiness, attentive living, and the pursuit of truth as the path to life and favor. Believers are encouraged to set their minds on wisdom to gain insight and protection from folly and disaster.
psalmSummary: Psalm 82 calls on those with authority to defend the weak, protect the poor, and administer just judgment rather than favoring the powerful. It warns that those who misuse power — though called 'gods' — will share mortal fate if they pervert justice. The psalm affirms that righteous judgment manifests God’s presence; failure to uphold justice brings collapse and exposes leaders to divine accountability.
gospelSummary: Luke 17:11–19 narrates Jesus' encounter with ten lepers who call for mercy from afar. Jesus directs them to present themselves to the priests; as they obey and go, they are cleansed. Only one—identified as a Samaritan—returns to Jesus, throwing himself at his feet and giving thanks, and Jesus commends his faith. Luke contrasts mere physical cure with the deeper recognition of God’s work: nine are healed but remain ungrateful, while the one outsider models faith, conversion, and praise. The episode challenges boundaries of ethnicity and religious expectation and highlights gratitude as integral to discipleship and salvation. It insists that faith is visible in thanksgiving, and that God’s mercy crosses human divisions.
saintReflection: St. Josaphat (Memorial): Josaphat (1580-1623), Archbishop of Polotsk, was a Ukrainian Greek Catholic monk who sought unity between Orthodox and Catholic Christians and died a martyr for his efforts.
dailyPrayer: Lord Jesus, physician of body and soul, you show mercy to those who cry out for healing and you welcome the gratitude of the humble. Give us hearts that recognize your gifts and mouths that return praise. Teach us to seek wisdom early, to defend the poor and vulnerable, and to administer justice with courage. Through the intercession of St. Josaphat, grant us the grace to work for unity among Christians, even when it costs us. Strengthen our faith so that gratitude becomes the sign of our encounter with you, and make us instruments of reconciliation in our families and communities. Amen.
theologicalSynthesis: The readings unite themes of wisdom, justice, healing, and grateful faith. Wisdom calls for vigilance and moral preparation; the psalm summons leaders to defend the weak and render just judgment; the Gospel shows healing coupled with the demand for grateful recognition and faith. St. Josaphat’s life models crossing divisions to seek reconciliation, embodying costly fidelity. Together these texts teach that true discipleship blends intellectual discernment, public justice, personal gratitude, and courageous sacrifice for the unity of the body of Christ.
exegesis:
Context: Wisdom 6:1–11 belongs to a corpus that extols wisdom as a salvific treasure, urging earnest pursuit and moral vigilance. Addressed to those who would live well under God’s rule, the passage frames wisdom as a way of life that prepares one like a watchman anticipating dawn. In the first-century Mediterranean world, such exhortation served both personal piety and communal stability: wisdom cultivates prudence, restraint, and right judgment in complex social circumstances.

Psalm: Psalm 82:3–4, 6–7 speaks directly to judges and officials, demanding defense of the oppressed and equitable judgment. Its stark warning — that those called 'gods' will die like men when they fail — confronts the misuse of authority. Read in the lectionary on this day, the psalm functions as a prophetic critique: public power must be service, not privilege. The psalm’s force is ethical and theological, linking leadership to covenant responsibility and divine accountability.

Gospel: Luke 17:11–19 narrates a simple but theologically rich episode: ten lepers are healed, yet only one, a Samaritan outsider, returns to give thanks. Luke shapes the scene to highlight faith and gratitude as the deeper responses to God’s mercy. The instruction to show themselves to the priests roots the event in Israel’s ritual order, while the Samaritan’s return subverts ethnic and religious expectations. Jesus’ commendation of the Samaritan’s faith reframes healing as a sign pointing beyond physical restoration to salvific encounter.

Saints: St. Josaphat (1580–1623) sought reconciliation between Orthodox and Catholic Christians and was martyred for his efforts. His ministry resonates with the Gospel’s crossing of boundaries: like the Samaritan who steps across ethnic lines to worship, Josaphat crossed confessional divides pursuing unity. His witness puts flesh on the readings’ themes by showing that gratitude, justice, and the pursuit of wisdom often require public courage and a willingness to suffer for the good of the Church.

Today: The texts challenge contemporary Christians to integrate private piety and public responsibility. Wisdom invites preparedness and moral formation; the psalm demands that leaders protect the vulnerable; the Gospel calls every believer to recognize God’s action and return with thanksgiving. In a fractured world and a divided Church, St. Josaphat’s example urges costly reconciliation. Practically, the readings press us to examine how our gratitude shapes communal life, how those in authority serve the poor, and how we, as disciples, cross boundaries to witness to God’s healing mercy.
